;香港资深登山教练梁志豪一直建议学生坚持口头禅“跟随你的心，倾听你的身体”，以免在酷热的农村遇到麻烦。

;

;本周他一直在重申这一建议，因为极端气温导致数名徒步旅行者被送往医院，其中包括一名63岁男子星期六在大埔张排屯怀疑中暑而短暂晕倒。

;

;另外三名登山客在西环东涌登山时亦需住院治疗Kung 和 Tsing Yi 星期二。

;

;从事山地工艺教学已有 20 年的 Leung 说，由于长时间暴露在阳光下和高温下，徒步旅行者会患上与热有关的疾病，包括疲劳和中暑。身体未能及时调节体温。

;

;香港女子沿海远足时被卷入海中死亡

;

;这种情况可能发生在体力活动和摄入不足的情况下水。与热有关的疾病的早期迹象可能包括神志不清、皮肤发烫或发红，或者体温超过 40 摄氏度（104 华氏度）。

;

;“他们带的水很少，以避免负重或不负重Leung 谈到因高温而屈服的徒步旅行者时说：如果气温飙升至周二和周三的记录，3 升，市区最高温度超过 34 度，上水观测到 37 度。

;

;Leung 还建议再补充 500 毫升（19 液量盎司）水随身携带作为备用。他补充说，补充电解质的饮料或茶等饮料不算在内。

;

;家佣在香港登山点掉进泳池身亡

;

;炎炎夏日，他在规划路线时，教练会检查天文台报告的高温指数和湿度数据，并随时准备改变路线以避免高温风险。

;

;他说他不会建议继续执行计划或仅仅根据计划搁置

;

;香港警方准备推出“HKSOS”应用程序以快速查明迷路的徒步旅行者

;

;“如果气温达到 37 度，我们将改变路线以包括通风区域有树荫。海拔也会降低，”Leung 说。

;

;专家表示，在如此高的温度下，海边路线和荒山小径之间会有很大差异，并指出流动性

;

;Leung 表示，近年登山死亡人数增加的一个主要原因是登山者高估了自己的身体状况，而没有充分意识到环境风险。

;

;“有些人会在看到 YouTuber 的路线剪辑后就出去，但无法估计他们是否能够应付，”Leung 指出，并补充说徒步旅行者也没有携带足够的防护装备。

;

;香港发出今年首个「酷热天气」警告

;

;远足者应始终诚实面对自己的能力，并可随时调整计划路线并在必要时撤离。

;

;“我们常说‘听从你的心，听听你的身体’……但很多人只是听从他们的心，而没有听从他们的身体发出的信号。”

;

;他提醒徒步旅行者不要独自散步，因为

;

;59岁的远足者在香港郊野公园小径上病倒后不治身亡

;

;50多岁的远足爱好者Winnson Wu表示，他喜欢挑战，即使温度达到35度，也不会放弃计划或任意退出。

;

;但他强调，他会休息一下，会留意身体发出的警报信号。 Wu 的基本装备包括帽子、宽松的衣服、防晒霜和足够的水——通常需要 1.5 到 2 升水来进行两小时的旅行。

;

;Wu 分享了一次独自徒步旅行的经历，当时他感到轻微的体征即将中暑。他在阴凉处休息了大约 20 分钟，喝了水，并在头上放了一条湿毛巾。

;

;他说他还准备在情况恶化时拨打 999，并强调徒步旅行者保持安全的重要性能够在手机应用程序的帮助下向救援人员准确报告他们的位置。

;

;“如果我今天挑战失败，明天我可以做到。无需将您的生活与徒步旅行捆绑在一起，”他警告说。

; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 15:50:02 +0800 Despite ‘no limits’ ties, China has moved carefully on Russian energy since Ukraine invasionhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3222493/despite-no-limits-ties-china-has-moved-carefully-russian-energy-ukraine-invasion?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.01 15:00;
;;

;自莫斯科 2 月入侵乌克兰以来，中国仅适度扩大了与俄罗斯的能源联系2022 年，根据一项新的分析，谨慎的做法与习近平主席和弗拉基米尔·普京总统在战争开始前宣布的“无限”伙伴关系不一致。

;

;俄罗斯石油和天然气在中国石油和天然气中的份额到 2022 年，这些产品的总进口额从一年前的 14% 上升到 16%。根据瑞典国际事务研究所独家与邮报分享的一项全面的新分析，2023 年前四个月的增长率高达 16.9%。

;

;中国公司没有进行新的投资或交易自普京发动入侵以来，俄罗斯的碳氢化合物行业一直处于紧张状态，也没有就任何新的石油或天然气管道或长期进口合同达成一致。

;

;虽然北京一直在抨击西方对俄罗斯能源行业的闪电式制裁，研究指出，中国基本上没有破坏它们。

;

;中国抗议美国对与俄罗斯打交道的公司实施“非法”制裁

;

;中国没有提供其国有油轮船队研究称，此举将“单枪匹马”消除俄罗斯现在被迫出售其石油的大部分折扣。

;

;它也没有在之后提供替代运输保险西方保险公司被迫与俄罗斯断绝关系。

;

;它继续以高于 G7 去年 12 月规定的价格上限的价格购买俄罗斯石油，但只能通过第三方或中国私营企业购买。

;< p>;调查结果显示，北京在“支持其最重要的战略伙伴挑战西方主导的世界秩序”和“照顾其自身更以自我为中心的利益，包括与西方国家保持经济联系”之间取得平衡贸易伙伴”，该报告称。

;

;该研究所的访问学者、该报告的作者 Henrik Wachtmeister 表示，北京的克制可能是因为受到来自西方的二次制裁的威胁。< /p>;

;中国可能不希望依赖俄罗斯的能源，但它也有时间：随着战争进入第 16 个月，石油和天然气将在未来一段时间内以折扣价供应.

;

;随着对莫斯科的一系列严厉制裁在 2022 年展开，许多人预计中国将填补西方买家和投资者留下的空白。

;

;相反，过去15 个月加速了中俄关系的不对称——法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙上个月将这种趋势描述为“一种附庸化形式”。

;

;俄罗斯仍然是中国能源结构的重要贡献者，但并非主导者，而中国在俄罗斯能源出口中的份额几乎翻了一番——从 16% 增加到 30%。

;

;虽然中国现在是俄罗斯能源产品的第一大买家，也是俄罗斯最大的油气资产外国所有者国家，这是因为西方公司退出了，而不是中国采购的大幅升级。

;

;在欧盟禁运之后，亚洲获得了大部分俄罗斯暗燃料——中国、印度是主要进口国

;

;眼睛- 报告称，去年俄罗斯液化天然气 (LNG) 进口价值增长 44% 和管道天然气增长 50% 主要归因于价格上涨，这也符合广泛的趋势中国在寻求减少煤炭使用的同时从世界各地吸取天然气。

;

;Wachtmeister 表示，只要与西方国家（尤其是欧洲）保持相对友好的关系，中国就可能会继续保持谨慎态度。

;

;这可能很快就会受到考验：布鲁塞尔目前正在讨论自战争开始以来针对中国运营商的首次以俄罗斯为中心的制裁。

;

;来自中国大陆或香港的八家公司因将欧盟制造的军民两用产品再出口给与俄罗斯军方有关联的买家而受到处罚的公司名单草案。

;

;欧盟考虑对被控帮助俄罗斯军方的中国公司实施制裁

;

;此外，一项新文书正在讨论中，该文书将限制向涉及违反制裁的第三国的出口。然而，这遭到了包括德国在内的一些国家的反对，他们担心会进一步损害欧盟与中国的关系。

;

;虽然这些潜在的制裁没有能源重点，但一些人担心他们会把中国推得更近

;

;北京驻欧盟大使傅聪警告称，中国将进行报复，而欧盟官员拒绝接受傅聪在接受新媒体采访时提出的帮助调查这八家公司的提议。政治家上周日。

;

;“规避制裁绝对是欧盟的首要任务，”欧盟委员会首席发言人埃里克·马默 (Eric Mamer) 说。 “我不能说现阶段我们是否与中国有任何具体的双边接触——我不知道这一点，但我们当然注意到你提到的评论。”

;

;Wachtmeister 建议为了鼓励中国在与俄罗斯的能源贸易中保持“最初的谨慎态度”，欧洲应该谨慎行事。

;

;“现在在这些领域使用大棒可能还为时过早，胡萝卜方法可能在不需要升级的情况下仍然有效。或许 [Theodore] Roosevelt 的‘说话轻声细语，大棒大棒’的方法就足够了，不是使用它，而是做好必要的准备，”他说。

;

;制裁不太可能在本周结束。

;

;欧盟大使周三开会讨论委员会的一项新提案，而一些成员国继续对任何类似于美国多年来实施的域外制裁的措施犹豫不决，这对欧洲的影响很大

;

;“危险在于我们过于偏向治外法权，”一位欧盟高级官员在谈到针对特定国家而非公司的辩论时说。 “我们需要确保这在法庭上成立。”

;

;该官员表示，欧盟对上个月访问包括布鲁塞尔在内的欧洲各国首都的中国和平特使感到失望。

;

;“我们没有了解到有关中国立场的任何新信息，”他们谈到与北京欧亚事务特使李辉的会谈时说。 “我们希望和平符合国际法。这是重申我们立场的机会，希望当他向习近平汇报时，他能听到（来自所有欧洲国家首都的）同样的话。”

; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 15:20:02 +0800 Republican 2024 field gets crowded with Mike Pence, Chris Christie to announce bidshttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3222574/republican-2024-field-gets-crowded-mike-pence-chris-christie-announce-bids?utm_source=rss_feed

;美国前副总统迈克彭斯和前新泽西州州长克里斯克里斯蒂计划参加下周 2024 年共和党总统候选人提名的角逐，挑战领跑者唐纳德特朗普的主导地位。

;

;克里斯蒂曾在 2016 年为特朗普的竞选活动提供建议，但后来却直言不讳地批评前者一位知情人士说，总统将于 6 月 6 日正式宣布他的 2024 年竞选活动。

;

;彭斯因拒绝支持他推翻 2020 年大选结果的努力而招致特朗普的愤怒，他将在三位熟悉情况的消息人士告诉路透社，他将于 6 月 7 日参加与他的前任老板的竞选。

;

;据一位知情人士透露，北达科他州州长 Doug Burgum 也计划与彭斯在同一天参加竞选熟悉 Burgum 的计划。

;

;越来越多的共和党人关注共和党内部的许多特朗普反对者。他们担心大量挑战者会分裂反对特朗普的投票，并将党内提名交给前总统，后者可以依靠至少 30% 的共和党选民支持他。

;

;特朗普有在共和党领域的巨大民意调查领先优势，现在有超过 10 名已宣布或几乎已宣布的候选人。最接近他的挑战者是上周参加竞选的佛罗里达州州长罗恩德桑蒂斯。

;

;德桑蒂斯在 2024 年竞选摇摆开始时抨击特朗普

;

;周三，彭斯在共和党领域的平均支持率低于特朗普根据 RealClearPolitics 的民调平均值，特朗普的支持率为 53%，超过 4%。克里斯蒂迄今为止几乎没有在民意调查中登记。

;

;消息人士称，彭斯将在爱荷华州的早期提名州通过视频和演讲启动他的竞选活动。

;

;一个坚定的社会彭斯是特朗普在任期间一直支持他的保守派，但自从他在选举失败后，他与这位前共和党总统的关系越来越疏远，他说特朗普对 2021 年 1 月 6 日袭击美国国会大厦的骚乱者的鼓励使他和他的家人陷入困境

;

;彭斯将于 6 月 7 日迎来 64 岁生日，他继续拥护特朗普的许多政策，同时将自己描绘成一个稳重且以共识为导向的替代者。他还更直接地向福音派基督教社区发出呼吁。

;

;他竞选活动的成功将取决于他能否吸引足够多的特朗普政策支持者，这些人对前总统的言论和行为感到厌恶，从而建立一个可行的联盟。

;

;60 岁的克里斯蒂以明显的失败者身份参加竞选，六年后，他在 2016 年总统竞选中未能在包括特朗普在内的拥挤的领域中获得牵引力。

;

;只有 1在 5 月 9 日至 15 日进行的路透社/益普索民意调查中，% 的共和党人表示他将成为他们首选的 2024 年候选人。

;

;克里斯蒂将在早期提名州圣安瑟姆学院的市政厅正式启动他的竞选活动知情人士说，周二新罕布什尔州参选。

;

;其他参加竞选的共和党人包括美国参议员蒂姆·斯科特和前南卡罗来纳州州长妮基·黑莉。

; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 15:20:02 +0800 McCarthy’s moment: US debt win secures Republican House speaker’s standinghttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3222565/mccarthys-moment-us-debt-win-secures-republican-house-speakers-standing?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.01 14:23;
;;

;周三，凯文·麦卡锡 (Kevin McCarthy) 赢得了美国众议院共和党议长的荣誉，面对激烈的强硬派反对，通过一项包含联邦支出限制的债务上限法案，乔·拜登总统数月来誓言要抵制这一法案。

;

;在他为了当选议长而忍受 15 次羞辱性的全场投票六个月后，麦卡锡证明有能力将拜登拖入关于支出和其他共和党优先事项的谈判，然后调集他经常脾气暴躁的众议院共和党多数派的三分之二来制定两党立法。

;

;“这不是你如何开始，而是你如何结束，”麦卡锡投票结束后，他对记者说，重复了他在 1 月晚上发表的一项评论，他最终被确认为议长。

;

;众议院以 314-117 的票数通过了该法案，该法案提高了政府 31.4 万亿美元的债务上限以换取削减非国防可自由支配开支和加强援助计划中的工作要求。

;

;然而，这对麦卡锡来说是一次伤痕累累的胜利。该法案获得了民主党人的 165 票，超过了麦卡锡所在的共和党成员的 149 票。

;

;该法案现在已提交给民主党控制的参议院，参议院必须颁布该法案并在 6 月之前将其提交给拜登的办公桌5 以避免严重的美国违约。

;

;北京对蔡英文访美的愤怒掩盖了共和党在乌克兰问题上的转变

;

;共和党国会议员 Dusty Johnson，麦卡锡的盟友，帮助制定了共和党的债务上限在谈判中支持议长的立法表示，投票证明民主党的预测是错误的，即这位 58 岁的加利福尼亚人几乎没有机会将他的党团聚在一起。

;

;“他们说他永远不会成为议长，并且当然他们错了。他们说他永远无法有效地管理场地，我们没有一个法案失败，”约翰逊在接受采访时说。 “他们说他无法与总统达成协议，但他们错了。”

;

;麦卡锡迄今为止成功地通过了该法案，没有招致前总统唐纳德的直接口头攻击特朗普敦促共和党人在无法从民主党那里获得足够让步的情况下推动违约。

;

;寻求在 2024 年重返白宫的特朗普抨击参议院共和党领袖米奇麦康奈尔感谢拜登上任第一年同意提高债务上限。

;

;在这些会谈中，麦康奈尔基本上处于幕后，在拜登于 5 月 9 日同意进行一对一谈判后，谈判开始向前推进。

;

;避免激怒特朗普似乎保护了麦卡锡在全国共和党选民中的地位，在 5 月份的路透社/益普索民意调查中，约 44% 的人表示他们认可他的工作表现，明显高于麦康奈尔的 29%

;

;众议院周三批准的法案将在 2025 年 1 月 1 日之前暂停债务上限——本质上意味着它不再适用。这为接下来几周的另一场摊牌奠定了基础2024 年总统大选。

;

;共和党立法者和分析人士表示，麦卡锡让拜登走上谈判桌的绝招是，他决定将债务上限法案带到谈判桌上，并在仅得到本党支持的情况下于 4 月通过。

;

;在此之前，拜登拒绝了麦卡锡就债务上限进行谈判的要求，坚持要求众议院共和党人制定自己的 2024 财年预算，作为支出谈判的先决条件。

;

;但在 4 月的措施获得通过后，众议院共和党人成为华盛顿唯一采取行动提高债务上限的机构。

;

;随着 2024 年竞选活动的开始，德桑蒂斯抨击特朗普

;

;“一旦参议院共和党领袖米奇·麦康奈尔 (Mitch McConnell) 的前高级助手罗希特·库马尔 (Rohit Kumar) 说，“如果众议院通过了一项法案，‘不谈判’显然是一个不可持续的地方。”

;

;白宫则辩称，拜登和麦卡锡之间的会谈不是关于债务上限的谈判。

;

;“债务上限必须取消，而且必须解除了很长一段时间，”白宫预算主管沙兰达·杨在周二的新闻发布会上说。 “你看到这个法案将债务上限提高到 2025 年。你可以称之为谈判；我称其为声明性声明。”

;

;众议院共和党人表示，麦卡锡作为发言人取得了成功，因为他具有包容性的领导风格，通过主要政党核心小组（被称为“五个家庭”，指的是电影《教父》中交战的有组织犯罪集团。

;

;“麦卡锡议长的工作令人难以置信，”强硬的共和党众议院自由核心小组成员、女议员马乔里·泰勒·格林说。 “而且我认为他一次又一次地证明了他战胜了困难，他也违背了人们的期望。”

;

;麦卡锡还通过值得信赖的朋友和长期合作伙伴扩大了他的影响力，例如国会议员帕特里克麦克亨利和加勒特格雷夫斯，成为他与白宫的首席谈判代表。

;

;但麦卡锡并没有完全走出困境。在激起强硬派保守派的愤怒之后，他们谴责妥协法案是背叛，他可能面临被任何一个成员推翻的前景。

;

;他在 1 月份同意的条件之一是赢得了议长席位允许任何一名成员提出“让出主席的动议”，实质上是就是否罢免议长进行投票。

;

;自由核心小组的高级成员表示，他们将考虑下一步行动

;

;他们中的一员拉尔夫·诺曼 (Ralph Norman) 表示，麦卡锡本应迫使民主党人接受众议院通过的法案。

;

;“我认为这削弱了他。 Norman 说：“我不知道这是永久性的还是暂时的，”Norman 说。

;

;但 Norman 表示，他不会支持立即罢免麦卡锡的议长职务，并补充说：“现在威胁要把他赶出去，那是不对”。

;

;2015 年，类似的威胁导致前众议院议长约翰·博纳 (John Boehner) 辞职。

;

;“这是蜜月期绝对可以结束的地方，”共和党战略家罗恩·邦让 (Ron Bonjean) 说，前众议院议长丹尼斯·哈斯特 (Dennis Hastert) 的一次性助手。

;

;本周，当被问及他是否希望继续担任议长一职时，麦卡锡告诉记者：“你怎么看？你们一直问我，我仍然站着。”

;

;他的盟友说他们会保护他免受任何对其地位的潜在威胁。

;

;“我们将处理一场艰苦斗争的内部政治。现在脾气暴躁，情绪低落。但我们会处理它，”麦卡锡顾问、国会女议员凯利·阿姆斯特朗 (Kelly Armstrong) 说。

;周四，澳大利亚最受勋的士兵之一在一场针对主要报纸的具有里程碑意义的诽谤案中败诉。审判涉及谋杀、家庭暴力、恐吓证人和战争罪等指控。

;

;澳大利亚精英特种航空服务团前成员本·罗伯茨-史密斯 (Ben Roberts-Smith) 在 2018 年指控他参与其中后起诉了三家报纸六名手无寸铁的囚犯在阿富汗被谋杀。

;

;Roberts-Smith 否认了这些指控，并发起了数百万美元的诽谤案作为回应。

;

;但法官 Anthony Beskano 表示，这些文件已经证明他们的许多指控“基本属实”并驳回了此案。

;

;澳大利亚在阿富汗的战争罪行显示了庆祝军队的代价

;

;该判决被誉为澳大利亚媒体自由的重大胜利，记者兼被告尼克·麦肯齐 (Nick McKenzie) 在推特上写道：“正义。”

;

;在审判前，出生于珀斯的罗伯茨-史密斯是澳大利亚最著名、最杰出的士兵。

;

;他赢得了维多利亚十字勋章– 澳大利亚的最高军事荣誉 – 表彰他在阿富汗的“显赫英勇”，他的部队正在那里追捕一名塔利班高级指挥官。

;

;他会见了当时的伊丽莎白女王，他的肖像挂在堪培拉的澳大利亚战争纪念馆中。< /p>;

;但《时代报》、《悉尼先驱晨报》和《堪培拉时报》称，罗伯茨-史密斯备受赞誉的公众形象背后隐藏着一种犯罪行为模式。

;

;该报称，罗伯茨-史密斯踢了一个手无寸铁的阿富汗平民从悬崖上掉下来，并命令下属向他开枪。

;

;据说他还参与了对一名装有假肢的男子的机枪扫射，后来将假腿带回澳大利亚并使用

;

;这位高大的退伍军人还被指控在堪培拉一家酒店对一名妇女实施家庭暴力——裁决称这件事尚未得到完全证实——并参与“一场竞选活动”欺凌”一名战友。

;

;罗伯茨-史密斯和他的律师声称，其中五起杀戮发生在战斗中，而第六起则完全是虚构的。

;

;报纸和他们的记者在整个审判期间支持他们的报道，主要依靠捍卫真相。

;

;此案成为澳大利亚历时最长的诽谤案审判之一，40 名证人提供了有关澳大利亚特别官员行为的令人痛心的证据

;

;当地媒体估计法律费用已达到 1600 万美元，成为该国历史上代价最高的诽谤案之一。

;

;媒体律师表示他们将稍后将寻求“对申请人的赔偿费用”。

;

;罗伯茨-史密斯的辩护部分由三家报纸的竞争对手 Seven West Media 的老板资助。

;

;他被拍到在裁决前在巴厘岛度假，但没有出庭。

;Helen Zia 为了上大学而和她的父亲奋斗。

;

;她继续成为 1973 年第一批从普林斯顿大学毕业的美国女性之一。在那里，她成功地游说成立了一个亚裔美国学生协会。

;

;几年后，她要求当局在底特律将杀害华裔美国人 Vincent Chin 视为仇恨犯罪。她成功了。后来，她的书籍和文章展示了亚裔美国人所面临的暴力和歧视。

;

;Zia 似乎一直在抗争——而且抗争的理由从未停止。 “亚裔美国人被抨击为卡通人物，”她说。 “我们被称为傻瓜、极客、艺妓。超越种族诽谤，走向具有力量和影响力的社区是一场不会消亡的战斗。”

;

;事实上，即使在她打过所有的战斗之后，当前的情况仍然提出了异常严峻的挑战。

;< p>;“这一次感觉不一样，”齐亚在奥克兰的领导力研讨会上说。

;

;当人们开始将 Covid-19 大流行归咎于中国时，似乎某些亚裔美国人也会感到反感。

;

; p>;

;“我看到你们在点头，”她对人群说。 “你去了，'哦，s ***。'”

;

;没有人笑。

;

;“我们今天的处境是很多事情的结果，我们中的一些人，已经预测了一段时间，”Zia 说。

;

;在这些变化中，美国日益多样化，一些社会成员认为这是威胁。

;

;虽然这不是一个家喻户晓的名字对公众来说，这位 70 岁的活动家和作家是关心亚裔美国人问题和民权的先驱。

;

;以她的强硬言论和敏锐的智慧以及Zia 的热情洋溢，说话时充满活力和信念，令她的听众深受鼓舞，而且常常感到敬畏。

;

;在美国，Yelp 发现种族主义的反亚裔商业评论急剧增加

;

; Most men or women might have given up by now,” said Mary Yu Danico, professor of sociology and director of the Asian American Transnational Research Initiative at Cal Poly Pomona. “Racism – bias against Asian Americans – has flourished for a long time and it still exists in public and in private. Helen could have gone on to do something lucrative or with less stress. But you continue to hear her reasoning and her passion day after day.”

;

;Zia was an early proponent of what was once a novel idea: that Americans with roots in China, Japan, Vietnam and other Asian countries could unite as Asian-Americans to organise, and when necessary, agitate.

;

;The group identity would expand to more parts of Asia, such as India, and later include Pacific Islanders. Some believe it's not far-fetched to say that without Zia, May would not now be observed as Asian-American and Pacific Islander Island Month.

;

;To her, the important thing is her work, not herself. “I'm an example of speaking up,” she said. “Never a role model.”

;

;But to many, that is exactly what she is, and her life has been marked by a devotion to duty – duty she developed young.

;

;

;

;Born in New Jersey to parents from Shanghai, Zia was five when she began helping in her parents' floral novelty business, doing her share along with five siblings.

;

;Her father was convinced that instead of giving flowers to new mothers, consumers might buy something more creative. The elder Zia combined blue and pink duckies with a lamp shade, or a carousel with a music box, both items sporting cups for holding blooms. He trained his kids how to carefully assemble them.

;

;He was an educated man who wrote poetry, plays and a novel – and fiercely proud of his Chinese heritage. He taught his children to be the same. “Just remember, when Europeans were naked in caves, we were wearing silk,” he would say.

;

;Zia's mum barely knew English, while her dad spoke with a heavy accent, making him a target for mockery and racism.

;

;“The Chinese – we have always been regarded as perpetual foreigners,” younger brother Hoyt Zia recalled.

;

;As the 1960s unfolded, the Zias lived in a mostly-white New Jersey community near Philadelphia, but Hoyt and Helen Zia remember being increasingly exposed to a multiracial society and this prompted her interest in social justice campaigns.

;

;In “Asian American Dreams”, her groundbreaking book that is part memoir, part social history, she recounts a life-changing incident in secondary school when she discussed civil rights with two friends – Rose, who was black, and Julie who was white:

;

;“As I offered my thoughts, Rose abruptly turned to me and said: 'Helen, you've got to decide if you're black or white'. Stunned, I was unable to say that I was neither, that I had an identity of my own. I didn't know the words 'Asian-American'. It was a concept yet to be articulated.”

;

;Zia, who was her school's valedictorian, was determined to learn more about outside communities. But her father forbade her from pursuing higher learning.

;

;'I had to hide my ethnicity': Asian-American actor Michael Tow on his youth

;

;“She was accepted at every school she applied to and had a drag-out battle with him. He finally relented and let her pick Princeton, the closest of the schools she got in,” said Hoyt Zia, a retired lawyer. “Dad said Chinese girls didn't need an education, but my sister always had a fighting spirit. She knew she wouldn't get anywhere without getting educated.”

;

;After launching the Asian American Students Association, a group that has grown into a thriving presence on hundreds of campuses, Zia found a voice protesting US involvement in the Vietnam war while joining causes pushing for racial unity among low-income minority groups.

;

;Later, while enrolled in medical school in greater Boston, she detoured – heading to Detroit in 1976 to work in construction because she believed women were under-represented in the field.

;

;Her move brought her to the same city as Vincent Chin, who in 1982 was beaten to death by two white men with a baseball bat. At the time, Japanese carmakers were increasingly competing with US companies, and the men blamed the 27-year-old Chin for the loss of their jobs.

;

;Zia, who had added journalism to her repertoire, wrote about all aspects of the killing. Chin was not Japanese but he was Asian, and for his killers that was enough. Her work galvanised Asians-Americans in Michigan and across the country.

;

;By 1987, when filmmakers released the documentary “Who Killed Vincent Chin?” the intensity of the Asian-American movement rose to a new level – amassing unprecedented attention. Supporters marched on the streets with Zia, and in a first, the protesters included cooks and laundromat owners, along with engineers and lawyers, carrying signs demanding their civil rights.

;

;Thus, a generation of activists was born. And she continues to draw new supporters.

;

;“I had no idea that any of these events happened – that violence against Asians had blown up and continues to be out of control – until I tuned into a Zoom [call] and heard her emotional voice sharing this history,” said Sue Chao, a store clerk from China who relocated to Los Angeles in 2019. “I've been researching that history, and I see Helen Zia's name a lot. Thanks to her, I now realise how our cultural reality is shaped by the past.”

;

;Australian lecturer's 'anti-China' remarks spark discrimination concerns

;

;But the concept of a pan-Asian community is not universally embraced. A 2022 study by the Pew Research Center into Asian identity found that “many participants felt that neither 'Asian' nor 'Asian-American' truly captures how they view themselves and their identity. They argue that these labels are too broad or too ambiguous, as there are so many different groups included within these labels”.

;

;Still, the concept Zia helped launch decades ago remains strong and she remains in demand as a speaker at universities nationwide.

;

;Publicly, Zia has also been a force for LGBTQ rights, not hesitating to spotlight the intersection of being a lesbian with Chinese-American roots. She and her wife, Lia Shigemura, tied the knot in 2008 after California began issuing same-sex marriage licences to couples.

;

;One morning in Oakland, where Zia has made her home for more than two decades, the crowd at a conference hosted by the Center for Asian Pacific American Women would not stop clapping – even before she spoke – for their keynote speaker.

;

;The mood in the room, sombre as observers listened to her life story, turned electric – with most spectators recording her on their phones, scribbling notes or asking for a photo with the guest of honour afterward, including moderator Gia Vang, an NBC Bay Area TV news anchor.

;

;Initially, when asked to appear with Zia, Vang remembered thinking: “Wow. The Helen Zia, someone at the forefront of all the issues we care about. She's a real-life person advocating for us, not a myth.”

;

;One woman working with Asian elders asked about the health of Zia's parents. Two others wanted her autograph.

;

;Zia was quick to respond, whipping out a fine-point pen, joking: “And what do you do? It's probably me who needs your signature on my book.”

;

;On what keeps her going, Zia said: “Always have something to offer. Never think you're alone.”

;

;Then she was off to San Francisco – to the next scheduled talk, another chance to educate, to inspire others to action.

;A large white goose in southern China that has been “going to work” with its owner at a shop every day for four years has delighted mainland social media.

;

;The bird, known as Happy Goose, has 52,000 fans on Douyin. Over the past four years, she has been accompanying her owner, Wen, to work at her leatherware shop in Hunan province every day.

;

;In a video posted with the story, the Happy Goose is seen at the front of the shop, walking around while honking. When a passer-by touches it, it leans its head towards her hand for a pat.

;

;The Happy Goose's story began in 2019 when Wen's daughter gave her a goose for a pet. Since Wen runs her shop full-time, she thought she could take it to the shop when she worked, and ever since, Wen and Happy Goose have commuted to work together.

;

;Every morning, Wen rides the motorbike to work carrying Happy Goose in her lap. Happy Goose helps look after the shop like an assistant during working hours and they go home together at the end of the day.

;

;The videos Wen has posted online have been popular such as one where Happy Goose tries to get a dog out of the shop and another of her having fun with a little girl.

;

;So far, Wen has shared 853 videos of herself and Happy Goose at work and at home on Douyin.

;

;A video from last month showed Wen talking to Happy Goose in an attempt to prevent her from fighting with dogs and cats that hang around the shop.

;

;“What are you going to do? Start a fight?” Wen asks the goose in the video.

;

;“Ah, ah,” Happy Goose clucks in response.

;

;“You can't do that. Stay here and spend time with me,” Wen says.

;

;“Ah,” the goose clucks again.

;

;The story has amused many internet users in China.

;

;One person said: “Hahaha, the goose is very obedient.”

;

;“How adorable! It makes me want to raise one too,” another person said.

;

;In March, a stray puppy in eastern China begging its new owner also to adopt its teddy bear went viral.

;

;In the same month, a story about a pet dog in southwestern China that visited its sick owner in the hospital every day they were apart trended online.

;PricewaterhouseCoopers is facing increased scrutiny in Australia amid a Senate inquiry this week into the leaking of sensitive government tax policy to private clients as heads roll at the embattled consultancy giant and a criminal investigation gets under way.

;

;The scandal unfolded earlier this year after the former head of international tax for PwC Australia, Peter-John Collins, was deregistered for sharing confidential government briefings on new tax evasion laws with the company's partners and customers to allegedly help them benefit from the information.

;

;The misconduct has raised questions over ethics at deep-pocket big four firms and the potential for too cosy relationships between governments and their clients.

;

;PwC, Australia's biggest accounting firm, is now scrambling to salvage its reputation amid a crisis of public trust.

;

;The saga also echoes similar cronyism scandals at other global corporate behemoths, including the 2001 collapse of US energy titan Enron, whose problems were hidden by then big eight auditor Arthur Andersen.

;

;How Hong Kong can keep its edge after G7 tax deal

;

;During scheduled Senate hearings on budget spendings held this week, lawmakers grilled the Australian Tax Practitioners Board (TPB), the tax office, and the Australian treasury for failing to protect taxpayer funds and get to the root of the problem known to officials since at least 2018.

;

;The government last week referred the tax scandal to the Australian federal police for a criminal investigation. In 2018, the tax office alerted the police but attempts to seek more information from PwC were stonewalled by the company and investigations stalled.

;

;The tax office first got a whiff of the crisis when several multinationals quickly restructured their businesses in response to Australia's newly enacted tax avoidance laws in late 2015.

;

;Hundreds of pages of redacted PwC emails have since been published and some were read at the briefings, including Collins's comment to partners and staff: “OK in practice until the Australian Tax office (ATO) gets grumpy and figures out the joke”.

;

;The scandal also revealed many Australian government departments have million dollar contracts issued to PwC or have close links to the company including the ones tasked to investigate it such as the federal police and the TPB.

;

;Senator Barbara Pocock on Wednesday asked the chair of TPB Peter de Cure how it would “look” to Australian taxpayers that two of its conduct committee members were former PwC partners even though they did not participate in the investigations into PwC.

;

;“Let's not kid ourselves, people out there listening to this know what to look for here. Suspending PwC would be arguably the most consequential sanction that TPB has ever made,” Pocock said.

;

;“And you still sit around the boardroom with these two former partners. Do you understand how this looks for the average person out there paying their tax, the TPP is fundamentally compromised?” she asked.

;

;“And doesn't that explain why you've given PwC nothing more than a slap on the wrist?”

;

;TPB, which gave Collins a two-year suspension, told Pocock it wasn't legislated to levy penalties.

;

;Senator Deborah O'Neill also questioned treasury representatives on why it did not alert the relevant ministers when the matter came to light in 2018.

;

;“Were you at that point aware … that a scheme had been constructed to rob Australians of taxation that multinational companies should pay,” said O'Neill, who was subsequently told secrecy laws prevented the treasury department from obtaining more information.

;

;As the controversy ballooned, PwC Australia chief executive Tom Seymour resigned after published emails showed he was one of the recipients of confidential information Collins had leaked. The company also stood down nine partners but have not responded to the demands for their names.

;

;Senators have called for names of about 50 PwC partners and staff – gleaned through the leaked messages – to be made public, but PwC argued that it cannot be assumed everyone who were in the emails were involved in wrongdoing.

;

;Japan's tax man cometh for overseas evaders

;

;Prime Minister Anthony Albanese described what happened as “completely unacceptable.”

;

;Treasurer Jim Chalmers on Wednesday once again expressed outrage at PwC's conduct.

;

;“I think the country is absolutely filthy about what's happened with PwC,” Chalmers told public broadcaster ABC.

;

;“We want to be able to consult in good faith with the business community on changes that have the capacity to affect them, and people shouldn't monetise that for their own gain.”

;

;Observers, however, pinned the blame on ministers and government departments for turning a blind eye to the problem.

;

;“The theatre mounted by Treasury and Finance last week – the shows of outrage and referral to the Australian Federal Police – have been exposed as a confected farce,” financial commentator Michael Pascoe wrote in an opinion piece.

;

;Author and analyst Kim Wingerei asked in another comment piece why multinational tax avoidance experts were used to advise the Australian Tax Office.

;

;The scandal also reverberated on social media, with some calling for a blanket ban on PwC while others demanded the firm refund lost tax money.

;

;“Australia is run as a boys' club, operated by overweight middle-aged balding men who are never held to account. The protection they have as a boys' club to operate as criminals is astounding and will no longer be tolerated,” said a Twitter user.

;;

;Earth has pushed past seven out of eight scientifically established safety limits and into “the danger zone”, not just for an overheating planet that's losing its natural areas, but for the well-being of people living on it, according to a new study.

;

;The study looks not just at guardrails for the planetary ecosystem but for the first time it includes measures of “justice”, which is mostly about preventing harm for countries, ethnicities and genders.

;

;The study by the international scientist group Earth Commission published in Wednesday's journal Nature looks at climate, air pollution, phosphorus and nitrogen contamination of water from fertiliser overuse, groundwater supplies, fresh surface water, the unbuilt natural environment and the overall natural and human-built environment.

;

;Only air pollution wasn't quite at the danger point globally.

;

;Air pollution is dangerous at local and regional levels, while climate was beyond the harmful levels for humans in groups but not quite past the safety guideline for the planet as a system, the study from the Swedish group said.

;

;The study found “hotspots” of problem areas throughout Eastern Europe, South Asia, the Middle East, Southeast Asia, parts of Africa and much of Brazil, Mexico, China and some of the US West – much of it from climate change.

;

;Wildfires sparked 'Great Dying' of 250 million years ago, Chinese study confirms

;

;About two-thirds of Earth don't meet the criteria for freshwater safety, scientists said as an example.

;

;“We are in a danger zone for most of the Earth system boundaries,” said study co-author Kristie Ebi, a professor of climate and public health at the University of Washington.

;

;If planet Earth just got an annual checkup, similar to a person's physical, “our doctor would say that the Earth is really quite sick right now and it is sick in terms of many different areas or systems and this sickness is also affecting the people living on Earth,” Earth Commission co-chair Joyeeta Gupta, a professor of environment at the University of Amsterdam, said at a press conference.

;

;It's not a terminal diagnosis. The planet can recover if it changes, including its use of coal, oil and natural gas and the way it treats the land and water, the scientists said.

;

;But “we are moving in the wrong direction on basically all of these,” said study lead author Johan Rockstrom, director of the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research in Germany.

;

;“This is a compelling and provocative paper – scientifically sound in methodology and important for identifying the dimensions in which the planet is nearing the edge of boundaries that would launch us into irreversible states,” Indy Burke, dean of the Yale School of the Environment said in an email. She wasn't part of the study.

;

;The team of about 40 scientists created quantifiable boundaries for each environmental category, both for what's safe for the planet and for the point at which it becomes harmful for groups of people, which the researchers termed a justice issue.

;

;Rockstrom said he thinks of those points as setting up “a safety fence'' outside of which the risks become higher, but not necessarily fatal.

;

;Rockstrom and other scientists have attempted in the past this type of holistic measuring of Earth's various interlocking ecosystems. The big difference in this attempt is that scientists also looked at local and regional levels and they added the element of justice.

;

;The justice part includes fairness between young and old generations, different nations and even different species. Frequently, it applies to conditions that harm people more than the planet.

;

;Star swallows planet in first glimpse of Earth's likely end

;

;An example of that is climate change.

;

;The report uses the same boundary of 1.5 degree Celsius (2.7 Fahrenheit) of warming since pre-industrial times that international leaders agreed upon in the 2015 Paris climate agreement.

;

;The world has so far warmed about 1.1 degrees, so it hasn't crossed that safety fence, Rockstrom and Gupta said, but that doesn't mean people aren't being hurt.

;

;“What we are trying to show through our paper is that event at 1 degree there is a huge amount of damage taking place,” Gupta said, pointing to tens of millions of people exposed to extreme hot temperatures.

;

;The planetary safety guardrail of 1.5 degrees hasn't been breached, but the “just” boundary where people are hurt of 1 degree has been.

;

;“Sustainability and justice are inseparable,” said Stanford environmental studies chief Chris Field, who wasn't part of the research. He said he would want even more stringent boundaries. “Unsafe conditions do not need to cover a large fraction of Earth's area to be unacceptable, especially if the unsafe conditions are concentrated in and near poor and vulnerable communities.”

;

;Another outside expert, Dr Lynn Goldman, an environment health professor and dean of George Washington University's public health school, said the study was “kind of bold”, but she wasn't optimistic that it would result in much action.

;

;Additional reporting by Bloomberg

;Hong Kong police have arrested a 57-year-old woman on suspicion of animal cruelty, some 13 hours after two cats fell to their deaths from a public housing estate.

;

;A security guard at about 6am on Wednesday told officers the felines had been found dead outside Lok Wong House, part of Tsz Lok Estate, near Sheung Fung Street in Tsz Wan Shan, the force on Thursday said.

;

;An initial investigation found the two cats had fallen from a height, police added.

;

;Officers on Wednesday evening arrested the woman at Wong Tai Sin district, detaining her for animal cruelty, which is punishable by up to three years in jail and a HK$200,000 (US$25,535) fine.

;

;The woman was granted bail, pending further investigation, and must report to police later this month. Officers from the force's Wong Tai Sin criminal investigation unit are handling the case.

;

;Hong Kong dog dies from head injuries after alleged brutal abuse

;

;Hong Kong last month witnessed a string of animal cruelty cases, including the death of a nine-year-old Yorkshire terrier on May 8, a week after undergoing an operation to remove 18 fragments in its skull. The dog was believed to have been brutally abused.

;

;Police are searching for the boyfriend of the pet owner's mother in connection with the case. The Post had earlier learned the man had left Hong Kong.

;

;A day after the dog's death, officers arrested a Greek woman over a separate case of alleged animal cruelty after her 10-month-old Maltese died.

;

;A 22-year-old man was arrested on May 3 on suspicion of ill-treating his husky in another case.

;

;The incident came to light after an online video showed someone briefly attempting to strangle the dog using the flap of a metal cage as the animal hung its head outside the container through an opening.

;

;Hong Kong man arrested on suspicion of breaking wings of wild pigeon

;

;Police on May 17 also arrested a 66-year-old man for allegedly breaking a wild pigeon's wings, after the bird was discovered at a public housing estate in Tseung Kwan O.

;

;According to the force, the man was believed to be the same man featured in a video showing the suspected ill-treatment of another pigeon at the same estate a day before.

;

;The pigeons could have caused a nuisance and hygiene problems at King Lam Estate, leading the suspect to commit the alleged abuse, police said at the time.
